body: Doc change shouldn't appear in this branch. I'll fix that.
@javelinjs Any ideas?

This is usually caused by a mis-match in the DLL.
If you are using pre-compiled libmxnet.dll, you should download the
win10_x64_xxx releases instead of win2012_xxx. If you are building your own
dll, make sure you use the same machine/compiler/compiler options to
compile the DLL and the CPP code.

Thanks, but sadly say, the module.bind doesn't accept the grad_req as the argument. The error is 

TypeError: bind() got an unexpected keyword argument 'grad_req'

I have used the way of symbol.bind(grad_req=my_grad_req), it actually works. But the module does not support it...  
So I wonder why the inputs should be the args in MXNet. A network should be considered as a function, the inputs and outputs is external part and the parameters of network is internal part.

lint error depends on verion
you need to install this version of lint:
pip install cpplint 'pylint==1.4.4' 'astroid==1.3.6'
please update and recompile your mxnet

Just try to understand, any design reason to make RNN symbol to be time-major shape layout instead of batch-major? from my understanding, the low level symbol lstm.py process batch-major

`````` bash
scaladoc -toolcp ./assembly/linux-x86_64-gpu/target/mxnet-full_2.11-linux-x86_64-gpu-0.1.2-SNAPSHOT.jar `find ./ -type f -name "*.scala" -not -path "*core/src/test*" -not -path "*examples*"```
``````

Hi @piiswrong 

I still get the the error **Embedding layer doesn't support calculate data gradient** when I call backward of the decoder.

Here is my code, is there some wrong?

```
def build_lstm_decoder( self, is_train=True, bef_args=None):
    basic_sym = lstm_unroll(1, self.seq_len,len(vocab), num_hidden=self.hidden_size,
                            num_embed=self.embed_size, num_label=len(vocab))
    grad_names = basic_sym.list_arguments()

    def gen_dec_sym( seq_len ):
        sym = lstm_unroll(1, seq_len,len(vocab),
                          num_hidden=self.hidden_size,
                          num_embed=self.embed_size,
                          num_label=len(vocab))
        data_names = ['data'] + ['l0_init_c', 'l0_init_h']
        label_names = ['softmax_label']
        return (sym, data_names, label_names)

    grad_req = {}
    for name in grad_names:
        if name in ['softmax_label', 'data']:
            grad_req[name] = 'null'
        else:
            grad_req[name] = 'write'
    if is_train:
        decoder = mx.mod.BucketingModule(gen_dec_sym, default_bucket_key=self.seq_len+1, context=self.ctx)
        decoder.bind(data_shapes=[('data', (self.batch_size, self.seq_len + 1)),
                                  ('l0_init_c', (self.batch_size, self.hidden_size)),
                                  ('l0_init_h', (self.batch_size, self.hidden_size))],
                     label_shapes=[('softmax_label',(self.batch_size, self.seq_len + 1))],
                     grad_req=grad_req,
                     for_training=is_train,inputs_need_grad=True)

        decoder.init_params(initializer=mx.init.Xavier(factor_type="in", magnitude=2.34), arg_params=bef_args)
        decoder.init_optimizer(
            optimizer='adam',
            optimizer_params={
                'learning_rate': 0.02,
                'wd': 0.,
                'beta1': 0.5,
            })
```
Surprisingly it is working now. I can see expandable menus. Looks very useful for users reading mxnet docs.

@ameshkoff That's the reason we don't host prebuilt GPU package.

Different version of OS and CUDA can lead to fatal errors.

The sidebars are collapsed by default, which makes it hard to see the topics that the page goes over. I imagine that some users won't even realize that the sidebar is expandable -- I think at least one or two levels should be expanded by default: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/3888
Strictly no rpc is used yet . Data passing in pslite uses zeromq.but can be switched to other backends
You will need to rebuild the symbol, in python, use get internals api to get the corresponding output as output.  Get output only include the output nodes in the net.

because when you add two tensors they need to have the same shape.
You need certain pad size to ensure that.

Can we also move R test to jenkins?

It took quite a long time on travis now.
I think we should make this easier from the high-level interfaces.  I've also found myself wanting to get different outputs from the computational graph for different reasons.

We can certainly start with 1 level open by default on all pages.  Sometimes it will make sense to have more than that -- ideally this should be configurable on a page-by-page basis, maybe with a line of script, but I'm not sure how to express this in markdown.

OK, it looks like I figured out a problem. Actually it was not the installation problem but GPU out of memory. I should switch to NaiveEngine to catch errors and get "CUDA out of memory". Smaller datasets work fine both with NaiveEngine and multithreading.

@robert604 You should temporarily set environment variable MXNET_ENGINE_TYPE to NaiveEngine. It could help you to catch your error. As I could realize my build actually worked fine for me and it was just an "out of memory" error I couldn't catch due to multithreading engine.
More about environment variables for MXNet [here](http://newdocs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/env_var.html).

you should post you code and data list file then others can help you .   maybe your list file is wrong prepared?

do you mean using drop only in test with random drop the activation value?  if that, you should change the  forward fun in dropout op file, that is :  
- delete this line https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/dropout-inl.h#L90  
- delete the else part code, https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/dropout-inl.h#L108-L111  

BTW, why during test using the random drop method?

If you mean non-uniform probability It is likely we could do it via composition, now that we have mx.sym.uniform to generate uniform random numbers. One way would be

0.5\* (mx.sym.sign(prob - mx.sym.uniform(low=0, high=1)) + 1)

Thanks for the useful information above. adding "-L/usr/lib64/atlas" to ADD_LDFLAGS in config.mk and changing -lcblas to -lsatlas in mxnet/mshadow/make/mshadow.mk will fix the ld error on Centos 7 with ATLAS. I can also confirm that the ATLAS on centos 7 does not ship with libcblas.so. @tengpeng @thirdwing

in python this can be done with fixed_param_names in mx.mod.Module, not sure about R.

You probably have to manually specify grad_req={'weights_to_train':'write', 'weights_not_totrain':'null'} in symbol.simple_bind

By the way, I just have another question. From the C++ code, I see that the BatchNorm operator always uses global averaged statistics, no matter what the flag "use_global_stats" says, when the forward() is called with "is_train=False". Is there a simple way (from the Python interface) to make it use the batch statistics instead, when the network is doing inference? I have a use case which uses BatchNorm for a  different purpose from its original covariate shift reduction goal and this might require that I make the operator use the batch statistics during inference as well.

**[Updated]**
I am looking into this https://github.com/nicklhy/ResNet_caffe2mxnet

Hi @nicklhy, All,
do you guys have an updated script to convert Caffe ResNet weights to mxnet ones? I already tried [mxnet converter](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/tools/caffe_converter) but does not support resnet since mxnet misses some operators.

I get this while converting:

`  File "/home/iac/MXNet/mxnet/tools/caffe_converter/convert_symbol.py", line 169, in proto2script
    raise Exception('Unknown Layer %s!' % layer[i].type)
Exception: Unknown Layer Scale!
`

I have tracked that it seems not a solved issue [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/676) and [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/404)



Thanks,
iacopo

@iacopomasi , the converter in MXNet is not able to convert the resnet [here](https://github.com/KaimingHe/deep-residual-networks) since the different implementations of batch normalization. Kaiming He actually use BN(without learned gamma/beta)+Scale(to learn gamma/beta) in his caffe models, while MXNet can use a single BN to do that.
In my [resnet converter](https://github.com/nicklhy/ResNet_caffe2mxnet), I check the BN+Scale layers manually and replace them with MXNet BN layers. The code can be a little bit dirty due to this and some other inconsistent parameter settings over Kaiming He's resnet 50, 101 and 152. But anyway, you can use it to get the "almost same" MXNet models from the original ones.

BTW, I think on this page http://mxnet.io/tutorials/index.html we should make language the first level title and application categories the second level

I have met the same Problem and hope someone can solve it

Thanks for your answer tornadomeet, I think your suggestion might be equivalent to setting forward(is_train=True) in the predict call? This does provide dropout uncertainty but I believe it is only homoscedastic - i.e. it assumes that the uncertainty of the target variable in relation to predictor variables is consistent throughout the predictor variable feature space, which is not the case in my application. 

The reason to use random drop during test is to get a probabilistic output - i.e. with dropout on you can re-run predict x times to build up a probability distribution, the spread of which provides an indication of the uncertainty of the prediction. Yarin Gal has written a [very good article](http://mlg.eng.cam.ac.uk/yarin/blog_3d801aa532c1ce.html) about this.

Thanks for your answer tqchen. Would that allow the spread of prediction uncertainty for the target variable to become data dependent?

The aim is to achieve the lower of these two images, standard dropout uncertainty provides the upper:
![Homoscedastic dropout uncertainty](https://github.com/yaringal/HeteroscedasticDropoutUncertainty/raw/master/images/homoscedastic_dropout_reg_large_observation_noise.png)
